medium:
Yueh ware
High-fired stoneware with incised decor under a celadon glaze
title: Kuan Storage Jar
text: Building up coiled strips of rather coarse clay created the body of this relatively popular western Han vessel type. Applied to the shoulder area is a thin, yellowish-green glaze associated with several Western Han burials excavated in present day Kiangsu and Chekiang provinces. The jar has been fired at a relatively high temperature (about 1200 degrees C.) giving rise to its popular descriptive term, "proto-porcelain." Analysis of slightly later Eastern Han (1st century a.d.) green glazed ware from Shang-yu in Chekiang province shows that it was fired at about 1300 degrees C. making this type of Yueh ware, the first mature porcelain in China. Though difficult to produce, the serviceable quality of the well-bonded glazes and hard durable bodies of these early high-fired stonewares was greatly appreciated.
description: round-bodied jar with small foot; 2 applied handles with incised linear decoration; 3 rows of thin incised bands; top half glazed yellow-green
creditline: Gift of funds from C. Curtis Dunnavan
